data.title: ArtCare Conservation
data.meta_description: ArtCare Conservation is a leading fine art conservation company specializing in the treatment of paintings on canvas and panel. Learn more.
data.text:
Steve Gayler and Oliver Watkiss first met each other in 2004 while working together in England, where Steve joined International Fine Art Conservation Studios in Bristol UK after graduating from the Courtauld. Steve’s ambitions and desire to work on modern and contemporary artworks soon led him to the USA and eventually to New York, where he worked closely with Suzanne Siano, helping Suzanne establish Modern Art Conservation in NYC. During these years, Steve established himself as a leading paintings conservator, treating important modern and contemporary artworks.

In 2016, Steve left NYC and moved out West to Los Angeles. In LA, he began working for ArtCare, using his charisma and experience to establish a new studio. It was a realized dream for Steve and Oliver to work together again, albeit from different cities within the USA. It was sadly cut short in 2018 with Steve becoming increasingly ill. Steve sadly succumbed to his illness on September 25th, 2020.

Steve left an impression on everyone he met. He will be remembered for his playfully infectious charm, his love for everything Bond, especially Roger Moore, Cheese O’Clock, and his sublime use of language – with ‘anon’, ‘ciao,’ and closing emails with ‘Breast of duck!’ or ‘Bon Chance’ among the best. He was a great friend and colleague. Steve is greatly missed.

Oliver is our CEO and a Partner at ArtCare Conservation. His ArtCare journey began in 2013 following a move to the USA from Wiltshire, England. Born into a family of artists and conservation professionals, Oliver’s exposure to art began as a boy in his Father’s – one of the UK’s most respected structural conservators – studio.

As an adult, he went on to undertake formal training with NVQ from Strode College in conjunction with an apprenticeship with Richard Pelter at International Fine Art Conservation Studios in Bristol (IFACS), England. His research dissertation, titled “A Study of Contemporary Lining Adhesives and Their Comparable Properties and Suitability under Different Climatic Circumstances,” was widely praised.

Oliver went on to spend ten years with IFACS working on many large and high-profile projects, including a four-year conservation project of Oxford University’s Sheldonian Theatre’s ceiling paintings.

In 2008, Oliver became director of Richard Watkiss’s studio Lydeway Conservation in the United Kingdom, specializing in the structural conservation of old masters on canvas and panel. It was at Lydeway Conservation that Oliver was regularly called upon to work with the Royal Art Collection, Government Art Collection, National Trust, and English Heritage, as well as leading fine art dealers and private collectors.

Oliver has led numerous projects since joining ArtCare Conservation, including treatments on Albert Bierstadt’s Domes of Yosemite (1867), and Sandro Botticelli and Domenico Ghirlandaio’s Coronation of the Virgin and the Saints (1492). In 2019, as part of the Getty Institute’s Conserving Canvas Initiative, Oliver carried out the planning and implemented the conservation treatment of the Ringling Museum’s Jean-Joseph Benjamin-Constant, Emperor Justinian (1886). This project included training of eight mid-level painting conservators from worldwide institutions. The project closed with a structural treatment conservation workshop, which included four professors from painting conservation programs in the USA and Canada.

Veronica is our Director of Conservation and a Partner at ArtCare Conservation. She holds an enviable portfolio of academic achievements and professional credentials, including a BFA from the University of The Arts, Pennsylvania, conservation training from Lorenzo d’Medici in Florence, Italy, and the title of Professional Associate with the American Institute of Conservation.

Following her return from Italy to the USA in 2004, Veronica started work with our founder Rustin Levenson, where she was at the forefront of the company during its transition to ArtCare Conservation.

Veronica has a special expertise and extensive experience in treating Contemporary, Latin American, and European paintings.

In 2010, she was a volunteer participant for The Smithsonian Haiti Cultural Recovery Project to rescue, recover, and help restore Haitian artwork damaged and endangered by the earthquake and its aftermath.

She has given several presentations at meetings for the American Institute for Conservation. In 2008, Veronica spoke to the Paintings Conservation Group at the American Institute for Conservation on methods for flattening textured contemporary paintings. At the AIC meeting in 2009, she was co-presenter of a paper on the treatment of smoke-damaged paintings.

Kelly has been part of the ArtCare family since 2013. As Director of the New York Studio and a Partner in the business, she brings to the role a strong academic background with a BA in Art History and an MA in Museum Studies from the University of Florida, Gainesville; and Master of Art Conservation in Paintings from Queen’s University, Kingston, Canada.

Previous internships include the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, the Atlanta Art Conservation Center, and the National Gallery of Canada. Kelly’s extensive research on William Aiken Walker is part of the archives of the Florida History Museum in Tallahassee and the University of Florida. After completing Miami Heritage Responders training in 2017 through the Foundation for the Advancement in Conservation, her focus has been on disaster recovery and managing the treatment of large, private collections. Kelly is a Professional Associate of the American Institute of Conservation..

Javier Hernandez is our Managing Director and is a Partner in the business. Joining the ArtCare family in 2012, he is now a lynchpin in our leadership team – and oversees Business Development and National Accounts. He has played an active role in establishing relationships with organizations such as the Center for Contemporary Arts Santa Fe, Perez Art Museum, BFI Gallery, and his own artist run gallery, Placeholder.

Following his graduation from Cooper Union with a BFA in 2001, he managed a post-production studio in NYC. Javier’s commercial skills and strategic vision are coupled with his early-developed relationship with the art industry. This rare combination of skills has enabled him to support the company’s growth and future strategy.

Master of Art Conservation in Paintings from Queen’s University, Kingston, Ontario, and a BA in Art Conservation from the University of Delaware. After earning her graduate degree, Blanka held positions at a private Washington, DC-based firm, specializing in easel paintings and murals, and at the University of Delaware Program in Art Conservation, where she taught an undergraduate course in painting conservation and co-directed a UD study abroad program in Peru aimed to provide students with hands-on experience in the documentation and treatment of wall paintings.

Blanka has contributed to many large-scale projects in the U.S. and internationally, including the treatment of murals in the U.S Capitol Building, decorative paintings in the Mission San Miguel, CA, and Andean Baroque wall paintings in southern Peru.

Prior to joining ArtCare, Blanka worked at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art (LACMA) on the conservation of the Watts Towers of Simon Rodia, one of LA’s most iconic art landmarks, and on the Damascus Room, a painted and gilded wood interior from the late Ottoman period. She served a key role in project planning and management of the Watts Towers Conservation Project, and worked with conservation scientists and engineers in developing materials testing, treatment, and monitoring protocols, research which culminated in presentations at the 41st and 42nd AIC Annual Meetings and a paper in the AIC Objects Specialty Group Post prints.

Blair is one of our team’s talented Paintings Conservators. Joining us in 2020, she brings impressive academic credentials from both sides of the Atlantic including a BA in Art History and a BA in History from American University, Washington, D.C., as well as a Master of Arts with Distinction in the Conservation of Fine Art Easel Paintings Conservation from Northumbria University, UK. Her MA research dissertation focused on combining Aquazol with novel gelling agents as a lining adhesive for canvas paintings. Blair specializes in Southern European Old Master paintings, and over-sized paintings.

Previous positions include an Andrew W. Mellon Fellowship in Painting Conservation at the Detroit Institute of Arts and fellowships at The John & Mable Ringling Museum of Art in Sarasota, Florida. Blair also worked at the National Gallery of Ireland, and various Smithsonian Institution branches such as the National Portrait Gallery, Smithsonian Institution Archives, and the Museum Conservation Institute. Her presentations at AIC and ICOM-CC conferences include Titian’s painting methods, Artemisia Gentileschi’s materials and techniques, and modifying frame rebates for warped panel paintings. Blair has published articles on the painting methods of Andrea Sacchi, as well as methods and materials used by Pieter Bruegel the Elder in “The Wedding Dance.”

Blair is a Professional Associate of the American Institute for Conservation (AIC).

Founder, Advisor, New York, and Miami. B.A. Wellesley College; Diploma in Paintings Conservation, Fogg Art Museum, and Harvard University. Conservation staff of the Fogg Museum (1969-1973), the Canadian Conservation Institute (1973-1974); The National Gallery of Canada (1974-1977); and The Metropolitan Museum of Art (1977-1980). She has co-authored with art historian, Andrea Kirsh, Seeing Through Paintings: Physical Examination in Art Historical Studies (Yale University Press, 2000) and written chapters for The Expert vs. the Object (Oxford University Press, 2004) and the upcoming Painting Conservation Book to be published by Buttersworth Press.

Her published articles include “Emergency Conservation,” “Adhesives for Strip-Lining Twentieth Century Paintings,” “A New Method for Strip-Lining Easel Paintings,” “Useful Modifications for Current Lining Techniques,” and “Up in Smoke, the treatment of fire-damaged paintings.” She is a Fellow both in the American Institute for Conservation and The International Institute for Conservation, and has served on numerous professional committees as well as chairing the Paintings Specialty Group of the American Institute for Conservation.

Michael is the Studio Manager for the Miami Studio and a vital player in the studio’s daily operation. Outside of ArtCare, Michael is a practicing artist. He received a Bachelor of Fine Arts from New World School of the Arts, a Master of Fine Arts from Florida International University, and a two-time fellowship at the Ratcliffe Art + Design Incubator. Michael has shown nationally with group exhibitions at The Patricia and Philip Frost Art Museum in Miami, FL; The Bedroom Art Gallery in Curwensville, PA; and The Strohl Art Center in Chautauqua, NY.

Maija is the Studio Administrator for the New York studio. She earned her Bachelor’s Degree from Smith College in Art History and French with a concentration in Museum Studies. Her academic studies and own practices in painting and printmaking led to internships with the Endowment Fund of the Louvre (Paris, France) and the Hamilton Wood Type & Printing Museum (Two Rivers, Wisconsin) in their print shop. Following her graduation, Maija worked at LiveArt (New York, NY) as the Business Coordinator overseeing the logistical aspects of paintings sold through the company’s platform.

Maija joined ArtCare in 2023 to aid in the day to day operation of the New York studio, as well as to broaden her understanding of the field and the practical aspects of coordinating the movement of artworks.

Lindsey is a paintings conservator at the Miami Studio. She holds multiple associate degrees in Studio Arts, Art History, and Humanities, a Bachelor’s degree in Art History from the University of California Los Angeles, and a Master’s degree in the Conservation of Fine Art from Northumbria University, United Kingdom. Lindsey undertook extended training at Northumbria University in Medieval panel painting, furthering the development of a specialized skillset.

Lindsey has interned at the United Kingdom at The Laing Gallery, Newcastle, and Guildhall, London. She has professional experience working in a well-established, private studio based in Los Angeles, with particular experience in the disaster recovery of fire-damaged artworks. In her work for both museums and private collections, Lindsey has built a diverse portfolio that ranges from Old Master paintings to Modern & Contemporary artworks.

Sarah, a paintings conservator, joined the Miami team in 2023. She earned a BA in Art History and a BS Chemistry at Western Kentucky University. She then attended Northumbria University as a US-UK Fulbright Postgraduate Scholar for her Masters in Conservation of Fine Art. While studying, her research focused on materials used in traditional frescoes and panel paintings. Sarah completed a work placement at the Guildhall Art Gallery in London, focusing on traditional paintings. Prior to joining the ArtCare Conservation team, Sarah worked in a private studio in South Carolina. There, Sarah’s work had a particular focus on contemporary artworks, in addition to emergency response for fire and water-damaged artworks.

Olivia is an administrative assistant and pre-program conservation technician in the Los Angeles studio. She earned her Bachelor’s Degree from Hobart and William Smith Colleges in Studio Art and Art History. Olivia has experience as a studio assistant for sculptor and Professor, A.E. Ted Aub, and as a gallery assistant at the Davis Gallery in Geneva, NY. To advance her technical skillset, Olivia studied studio art in Rome, Italy, during her undergraduate career.

Olivia is currently completing her Chemistry requirements and intends to apply to a graduate program in art conservation in the near future. Under the guidance of Blanka Kielb and Kathryn Harada, Olivia continues to hone her technical skills in paintings conservation and broaden her knowledge in the field.
